messageBody:
I think I've answered my own questions over a morning break. Here is my
proposed solution:

For CustomerTest XTest, I'll create a constructor like XTest(name, host,
port) which will call super(name), store host and port.
For XTest.suite(), I'll check to see if host is 'localhost' (or
127.0.0.1) - if it is, start my local HTTP server (via a TestSetup
extension) with the set port (default value already applied). If the
host is not localhost, I'll simply skip the TestSetup and return the
suite.

In my super class, which handles communication via HTTP to the server
(local or otherwise), it will simply use the set host and port which was
either the default (localhost:randomport) or the provided host and port.

I can then setup a wrapper class for my CustomerTests, CustTestY. When
I build my suite I can do something like:

...
remoteHost = [some default host];
remotePort = [default port on remoteHost]

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite s = new TestSuite();
s.addTest(new XTest(remoteHost, remotePort);
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
... If there are args...
remoteHost = arg[1];
remotePort = arg[2];
...
junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
}

This would then allow me to run the wrapper class with a default, or
given (via commandline), host and port to point at.

Is this the best approach for me? Is my logic flawed? My apologies in
advance for not just hammering it out, but this is unfortunately a bit
of a background thought process for me while I clean up other tests and
I just wanted to bounce the idea off the list (for lack of another
suitable 'pair') first.

Thanks in advance,

Tom

-----Original Message-----
From: Thomas Robbs
Sent: August 27, 2003 9:28 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] HTTP Testing - Local and Remote



Greetings...

I'm finding myself in a situation where I would like to create the
following type of test case:

- testing a web service via HTTP
- default testing of the service would require that the HTTP server is
started up on the local machine
- an additional way of executing the test would be to have the same HTTP
based tests execute against an assumed host/port that is already running
the HTTP server w/ the service.

We're currently using XmlTestCase as the base class for an HttpTestCase.
The former handles the XML that is returned from the service and the
later handles getting the response to and from the server to our tests.
I currently use an extension of TestSetup to setup the HTTP server for
the "default test execution".

I'm not sure how to proceed. I'd assume that I may need to create my
own TestRunner to perform the "execute tests against remote server"
approach. I don't want to go down a rat hole on this as I think there
is a chunk of basic Junit knowledge that I'm missing out on as to how to
best set up this pattern.

Can anyone lend a hand or point me at some examples of solutions that
fix similar problems?

Thanks in advance,

Tom
